comment._content: I was just going to say it is the Shannon, because those barges with the tall chimneys are Shannon barges, methinks. Could it be Foynes before development? Or is it one of the junctions between the Shannon and one of the canals?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Yes, looking south from the bridge in town. The Weir is from 1844, and Wolfe Tone Terrace is not to be seen, so it's before the 1912 historic map survey.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Reverse view from the lock in the picture towards the bridge:

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Perfect match! You lot are good!

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Yes. "Big ass" is an engineering term. There's a description and history of the lock (and general navigation of the river in Athlone) on this site. They don't use the correct term - but I recon that's just because they wanted to avoid overly technical terms that might put-off casual readers. [PS: Yay! I helped with one. Now that this little "flikroonies" community is a little bigger I can't keep up. Genuine satisfaction at being able to chip in.]

comment._content: How do you link to a particular place in google maps? When I try it just takes you to the home page :-(

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: There's a button on the upper left that looks like a bit of chain. Click on that and it'll give you a URL.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Slight off topic segue, but Pauric from the Royal Irish Academy'll be on RTE's Drivetime programme this evening around 6.15 talking about the first ever radio sports transmission that took place at the Dun Laoghaire Regatta in 1898 - all in honour of 75th anniversary of the death of Marconi... Thought ye might be interested given some of our recent adventures in Marconi land!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Hmm, the angle may be wrong for Wolfe Tone Terrace, but by 1912 we should be able to see the little park below the weir, now Burgess Park: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,604113,741203,7,9

comment.author: 51739479@N02
comment._content: Just a thought re Dun Laoghaire Regatta in 1898, would it not have been called the Kingstown Regatta (official name between 1821 and 1921)?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Here is a page about the Shannon steamers irishwaterwayshistory.com/2012/05/11/fairies-squirrels-an... The author suggests that the "Fairy Queen" was built on the Clyde in 1893. www.clydesite.co.uk/clydebuilt/viewship.asp?id=20339 by David Asprey from the original records by Stuart Cameron. "Sold on 5/3/1897 to Shannon Development Company of Dublin for service on the river Shannon from Athlone 1906 transferred to Lough Corrib 1913 returned to the Clyde"
